Cookieless Is Not Near, It’s Here! - State of Digital PublishingJames Colborn9/6/2022

While we are all getting ‘ready’ for a cookieless future, there are two major considerations that just aren’t being discussed enough.

  function external_links_in_new_windows_loop() {
    if (!document.links) {
      document.links = document.getElementsByTagName('a');
    }
    var change_link = false;
    var force = '';
    var ignore = '';

    for (var t=0; t<document.links.length; t++) {
      var all_links = document.links[t];
      change_link = false;
      
      if(document.links[t].hasAttribute('onClick') == false) {
        // forced if the address starts with http (or also https), but does not link to the current domain
        if(all_links.href.search(/^http/) != -1 && all_links.href.search('www.stateofdigitalpublishing.com') == -1 && all_links.href.search(/^#/) == -1) {
          // console.log('Changed ' + all_links.href);
          change_link = true;
        }

          // forced
          // console.log('force ' + all_links.href);
          change_link = true;

        if(ignore != '' && all_links.href.search(ignore) != -1) {
          // console.log('ignore ' + all_links.href);
          // ignored
          change_link = false;

        }

    }

<script type="application/ld+json" class="saswp-schema-markup-output">
[{"@context":"https://schema.org/","@type":"VideoObject","@id":"https://www.stateofdigitalpublishing.com/opinion/cookieless-is-not-near-its-here/#videoobject","url":"https://www.stateofdigitalpublishing.com/opinion/cookieless-is-not-near-its-here/","headline":"Cookieless Is Not Near, It’s Here!","datePublished":"2022-05-10T00:20:19-04:00","dateModified":"2022-09-06T08:41:18-04:00","description":"While we are all getting ‘ready’ for a cookieless future, there are two major considerations that just aren’t being discussed enough.","transcript":"Despite the fact it feels like we’ve all just started 2022, it’s only days until the end of Q1. That’s another quarter closer to a digital advertising ecosystem without 3rd party cookies. While conversations are all talking about preparation and getting ‘ready’ for a cookieless future, there are two major considerations that just aren’t being discussed enough; the industry is far from ready and immediate opportunities are constantly being ignored. Let me explain.  The missing 40%  I watched a fantastic TED Talk video the other day by the late (and quite simply wonderful) Sir Ken Robinson in which he commented “innovation is hard because it means doing something that isn’t very easy; it means challenging what we take for granted”. I’d argue this is the primary reason why we’re not talking enough about the fact that time is running out for implementing alternatives to the 3rd party cookie. Simply put, as long as campaigns can be delivered in full using Chrome, we’re still taking cookies for granted. In the Ted Video, Sir Ken further comments; “the great problem for transformation is the tyranny of common sense; thinking that things can’t be done any other way as that’s how it’s always been done”.     What continues to surprise me, however, is the fact the industry dialogue is still talking about readiness and the ‘actions that are needed’ for a future without 3rd party cookies when we’re already waist deep in inventory pools that have been blocking 3rd party cookies for the past 4 years. That’s not a typo, the past 4 years! In some markets, the combined share of Safari and Firefox is greater than Chrome. On all of the impressions we’re able to monitor at Teads globally (and this is across the actions of 1.9BN people), the average missed opportunity is around 40% from Chrome and Firefox users, yet all eyes are still looking at Google because many can’t easily think of things being done any other way!  Not a question of when, but how  We move therefore need to question readiness. Are industry participants ready? In short, the answer is no. If we focus on publishers first, arguably the primary source of what’s available to advertisers to buy, a recent survey from Teads may help illustrate this point. Publishers believe - when asked to pick their primary initiatives for growth - that their focus for innovation and growth will come from contextual solutions (59%) and their own 1st party data (63%). Great if you are embracing contextual solutions and or predictive audiences built by machine learning and artificial intelligence. Adversely, the majority of publishers don’t have a strategy to get users to log-in (55%) for fear of disrupting the user experience and losing traffic and less than 20% have more than 2 out of 10 users logging-in today. Not so encouraging for those looking to adopt addressable identifier-based solutions.    Balance this supply conversation with areas of focus on demand. In February of this year, an eMarketer report (US Programmatic Digital Display Ad Spending 2022) suggests that the majority of advertisers and publishers are first and foremost looking to test ‘authenticated and or email solutions’ (63%) and, most positively embrace contextual solutions (52%). This said, the minority will be testing ‘cohorts or probabilistic modeling’ (at 33% and 28% respectively) which may well be misaligned with the timeline of what’s going to be available and when especially when advertisers themselves have to determine their own value exchange for getting the necessary permissions to continue to reach their consumers.    Now at this point, this article might seem negative toward an addressable future so I’d like to stress that I firmly believe that any consumer involvement in a value exchange to create that addressable connection is of huge importance. Important because it spans so much more than audience targeting, from measurement to planning and important because the consumer’s involvement is exactly what privacy advocates and technology providers are looking for as these changes are rolled out.  Update your digital priorities, today  What I’m really trying to convey is more of a reality check. A statement that says that while many solutions may have huge value, the question is one of timing, readiness and what can be achieved today, tomorrow and by the time the bell tolls on the demise of the 3rd party cookie.    AdTech should be making life as simple as possible for both advertisers and publishers to minimize the risk and maximize the opportunities associated with a cookieless future. I believe that, over time, there will be a usable share of traffic from unified identifiers yet at the same time, I also think that there will be a significant amount of audience volume derived from a publisher's own 1st party site data. Audiences, I might add, that are going untargeted today due to the industry's belief that things can’t be done any other way than with cookies.    If I could summarize this article in one statement it would be this; you need to be testing solutions now! You need to get comfortable with substitute alternatives for 3rd party cookies well before the end of this calendar year. Simply put, you cannot take for granted that there will be a like for like substitute for how you do things today so it’s time to accept and move forward.    AdTech should be making life as simple as possible for both advertisers and publishers to minimize the risk and maximize the opportunities associated with a cookieless future. I believe that, over time, there will be a usable share of traffic from unified identifiers yet at the same time, I also think that there will be a significant amount of audience volume derived from a publisher's own 1st party site data. Audiences, I might add, that are going untargeted today due to the industry's belief that things can’t be done any other way than with cookies.","name":"Cookieless Is Not Near, It’s Here!","uploadDate":"2022-05-10T00:20:19-04:00","thumbnailUrl":"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/kFMZrEABdw4/sddefault.jpg","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"James Colborn","description":"I’m a qualified and experienced business leader with years of working in marketing, product sales strategy, selling and operations roles. I’ve been fortunate to experience working for amazing companies in both the United Kingdom and United States in an online advertising industry that has given me challenge and excitement. \r\n\r\nFor the past 20+ years, I’ve led advertising and marketing practices for corporations like Microsoft, AOL and Verizon, around the globe. I’ve managed various disciplines during this time, from marketing, product marketing to sales strategy and operations. \r\n\r\nMy skill is simplifying a decision, a course of action, a business model or an argument by using data, logic and clarity. My business is using these skills to connect advertisers and agencies with their desired audiences, with outcomes and with insight. \r\n\r\nI am a great communicator. I lead with vision and direction. I thrive in execution and I revel in the success of those I work for and those I work with. I have won accolades at every company I’ve worked for in management, leadership and teamwork. \r\n\r\nOutside of the corporate world, I relish in coaching race car drivers to find success in our collective passion for autosports. While the environment is totally different, the process is exactly the same. Finding simplicity in race car telemetry and communicating actionable decisions for racers to make.\r\n\r\nSpecialities: marketing, product marketing, online advertising, digital marketing, leadership, coaching, management, sales strategy, programmatic advertising, search engine marketing, data strategy, data management, data analysis, sales enablement.","url":"https://www.stateofdigitalpublishing.com/author/james-colborn/","sameAs":["https://www.linkedin.com/in/colbornjames/"],"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://www.stateofdigitalpublishing.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/unnamed_5_2-125x125.jpg","height":96,"width":96}},"duration":"PT17M55S","contentUrl":"https://youtu.be/kFMZrEABdw4?t=311","embedUrl":"https://youtu.be/kFMZrEABdw4?t=311"},

							<img data-del="avatar" class='avatar pp-user-avatar avatar-90 photo ' height='90' width='90' src="https://cdn-bjkcl.nitrocdn.com/ZfEHGrbhkMgKTiTsiXTlOoOZBeNqAgPw/assets/images/optimized/rev-0054040/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/unnamed_5_2-125x125-90x.jpg" srcset="https://cdn-bjkcl.nitrocdn.com/ZfEHGrbhkMgKTiTsiXTlOoOZBeNqAgPw/assets/images/optimized/rev-0054040/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/unnamed_5_2-125x125-90x0.jpg 1x, https://cdn-bjkcl.nitrocdn.com/ZfEHGrbhkMgKTiTsiXTlOoOZBeNqAgPw/assets/images/optimized/rev-0054040/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/unnamed_5_2-125x125.jpg 2x, https://cdn-bjkcl.nitrocdn.com/ZfEHGrbhkMgKTiTsiXTlOoOZBeNqAgPw/assets/images/optimized/rev-0054040/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/unnamed_5_2-125x125.jpg 3x" />							</div> 
							<div class="frhd--auth-right">
								<h5>
								<a href="https://www.stateofdigitalpublishing.com/author/james-colborn/">James Colborn</a>								</h5>
																<div class="frhd--auth-social">

						<p>
						I’m a qualified and experienced business leader with years of working in marketing, product sales strategy, selling and operations roles. I’ve been fortunate to experience...<a href="https://www.stateofdigitalpublishing.com/author/james-colborn/">Read more</a>						</p>
					</span>
									</div>
							
			<span class="cb-itemprop" itemprop="reviewBody"><div class="poool-content-post"><div id="poool_paywall_post"><p>Despite the fact it feels like we’ve all just started 2022, it’s only days until the end of Q1. That’s another quarter closer to a digital advertising ecosystem without 3rd party cookies. While conversations are all talking about preparation and getting ‘ready’ for a cookieless future, there are two major considerations that just aren’t being discussed enough; the industry is far from ready and immediate opportunities are constantly being ignored. Let me explain.</p>
<h2><strong>The missing 40%</strong></h2>
<p>I watched a fantastic TED Talk <a href="https://youtu.be/kFMZrEABdw4?t=311">video</a> the other day by the late (and quite simply wonderful) Sir Ken Robinson in which he commented <em>“innovation is hard because it means doing something that isn’t very easy; it means challenging what we take for granted”. </em>I’d argue this is the primary reason why we’re not talking enough about the fact that time is running out for implementing alternatives to the 3rd party cookie. Simply put, as long as campaigns can be delivered in full using Chrome, we’re still taking cookies for granted. In the Ted Video, Sir Ken further comments; <em>“the great problem for transformation is the tyranny of common sense; thinking that things can’t be done any other way as that’s how it’s always been done”. </em></p>
<p>What continues to surprise me, however, is the fact the industry dialogue is still talking about readiness and the ‘actions that are needed’ for a future without 3rd party cookies when we’re already waist deep in inventory pools that have been blocking 3rd party cookies for the past 4 years. That’s not a typo, the past 4 <u>years</u>! In some markets, the combined share of Safari and Firefox is greater than Chrome. On all of the impressions we’re able to monitor at Teads globally (and this is across the actions of 1.9BN people), the average missed opportunity is around 40% from Chrome and Firefox users, yet all eyes are still looking at Google because many can’t easily think of things being done any other way!</p>
<h2><strong>Not a question of when, but how</strong></h2>
<p>We move therefore need to question readiness. Are industry participants ready? In short, the answer is no. If we focus on publishers first, arguably the primary source of what’s available to advertisers to buy, a recent survey from Teads may help illustrate this point. Publishers believe – when asked to pick their primary initiatives for growth – that their focus for innovation and growth will come from contextual solutions (59%) and their own 1st party data (63%). Great if you are embracing contextual solutions and or predictive audiences built by machine learning and artificial intelligence. Adversely, the majority of publishers don’t have a strategy to get users to log-in (55%) for fear of disrupting the user experience and losing traffic and less than 20% have more than 2 out of 10 users logging-in today. Not so encouraging for those looking to adopt addressable identifier-based solutions.</p>
<p>Balance this supply conversation with areas of focus on demand. In February of this year, an eMarketer <a href="https://www.insiderintelligence.com/content/us-programmatic-digital-display-ad-spending-2022">report </a>(US Programmatic Digital Display Ad Spending 2022) suggests that the majority of advertisers and publishers are first and foremost looking to test ‘authenticated and or email solutions’ (63%) and, most positively embrace contextual solutions (52%). This said, the minority will be testing ‘cohorts or probabilistic modeling’ (at 33% and 28% respectively) which may well be misaligned with the timeline of what’s going to be available and when especially when advertisers themselves have to determine their own value exchange for getting the necessary permissions to continue to reach their consumers.</p>
<p>Now at this point, this article might seem negative toward an addressable future so I’d like to stress that I firmly believe that any consumer involvement in a value exchange to create that addressable connection is of huge importance. Important because it spans so much more than audience targeting, from measurement to planning and important because the consumer’s involvement is exactly what privacy advocates and technology providers are looking for as these changes are rolled out.</p>
<h2><strong>Update your digital priorities, today</strong></h2>
<p>What I’m really trying to convey is more of a reality check. A statement that says that while many solutions may have huge value, the question is one of timing, readiness and what can be achieved today, tomorrow and by the time the bell tolls on the demise of the 3rd party cookie.</p>
<p>AdTech should be making life as simple as possible for both advertisers and publishers to minimize the risk and maximize the opportunities associated with a cookieless future. I believe that, over time, there will be a usable share of traffic from unified identifiers yet at the same time, I also think that there will be a significant amount of audience volume derived from a publisher’s own 1st party site data. Audiences, I might add, that are going untargeted today due to the industry’s belief that things can’t be done any other way than with cookies.</p>
<p>If I could summarize this article in one statement it would be this; <strong>you need to be testing solutions now! </strong>You need to get comfortable with substitute alternatives for 3rd party cookies well before the end of this calendar year. Simply put, you cannot take for granted that there will be a like for like substitute for how you do things today so it’s time to accept and move forward.</p>
<p>AdTech should be making life as simple as possible for both advertisers and publishers to minimize the risk and maximize the opportunities associated with a cookieless future. I believe that, over time, there will be a usable share of traffic from unified identifiers yet at the same time, I also think that there will be a significant amount of audience volume derived from a publisher’s own 1st party site data. Audiences, I might add, that are going untargeted today due to the industry’s belief that things can’t be done any other way than with cookies.</p>
</div></div></span>		</div>

readabilityObject.title: Cookieless Is Not Near, It’s Here! - State of Digital Publishing
readabilityObject.content:
I’m a qualified and experienced business leader with years of working in marketing, product sales strategy, selling and operations roles. I’ve been fortunate to experience...Read more

Despite the fact it feels like we’ve all just started 2022, it’s only days until the end of Q1. That’s another quarter closer to a digital advertising ecosystem without 3rd party cookies. While conversations are all talking about preparation and getting ‘ready’ for a cookieless future, there are two major considerations that just aren’t being discussed enough; the industry is far from ready and immediate opportunities are constantly being ignored. Let me explain.

The missing 40%

I watched a fantastic TED Talk video the other day by the late (and quite simply wonderful) Sir Ken Robinson in which he commented “innovation is hard because it means doing something that isn’t very easy; it means challenging what we take for granted”. I’d argue this is the primary reason why we’re not talking enough about the fact that time is running out for implementing alternatives to the 3rd party cookie. Simply put, as long as campaigns can be delivered in full using Chrome, we’re still taking cookies for granted. In the Ted Video, Sir Ken further comments; “the great problem for transformation is the tyranny of common sense; thinking that things can’t be done any other way as that’s how it’s always been done”.

What continues to surprise me, however, is the fact the industry dialogue is still talking about readiness and the ‘actions that are needed’ for a future without 3rd party cookies when we’re already waist deep in inventory pools that have been blocking 3rd party cookies for the past 4 years. That’s not a typo, the past 4 years! In some markets, the combined share of Safari and Firefox is greater than Chrome. On all of the impressions we’re able to monitor at Teads globally (and this is across the actions of 1.9BN people), the average missed opportunity is around 40% from Chrome and Firefox users, yet all eyes are still looking at Google because many can’t easily think of things being done any other way!

Not a question of when, but how

We move therefore need to question readiness. Are industry participants ready? In short, the answer is no. If we focus on publishers first, arguably the primary source of what’s available to advertisers to buy, a recent survey from Teads may help illustrate this point. Publishers believe – when asked to pick their primary initiatives for growth – that their focus for innovation and growth will come from contextual solutions (59%) and their own 1st party data (63%). Great if you are embracing contextual solutions and or predictive audiences built by machine learning and artificial intelligence. Adversely, the majority of publishers don’t have a strategy to get users to log-in (55%) for fear of disrupting the user experience and losing traffic and less than 20% have more than 2 out of 10 users logging-in today. Not so encouraging for those looking to adopt addressable identifier-based solutions.

Balance this supply conversation with areas of focus on demand. In February of this year, an eMarketer report (US Programmatic Digital Display Ad Spending 2022) suggests that the majority of advertisers and publishers are first and foremost looking to test ‘authenticated and or email solutions’ (63%) and, most positively embrace contextual solutions (52%). This said, the minority will be testing ‘cohorts or probabilistic modeling’ (at 33% and 28% respectively) which may well be misaligned with the timeline of what’s going to be available and when especially when advertisers themselves have to determine their own value exchange for getting the necessary permissions to continue to reach their consumers.

Now at this point, this article might seem negative toward an addressable future so I’d like to stress that I firmly believe that any consumer involvement in a value exchange to create that addressable connection is of huge importance. Important because it spans so much more than audience targeting, from measurement to planning and important because the consumer’s involvement is exactly what privacy advocates and technology providers are looking for as these changes are rolled out.

Update your digital priorities, today

What I’m really trying to convey is more of a reality check. A statement that says that while many solutions may have huge value, the question is one of timing, readiness and what can be achieved today, tomorrow and by the time the bell tolls on the demise of the 3rd party cookie.

AdTech should be making life as simple as possible for both advertisers and publishers to minimize the risk and maximize the opportunities associated with a cookieless future. I believe that, over time, there will be a usable share of traffic from unified identifiers yet at the same time, I also think that there will be a significant amount of audience volume derived from a publisher’s own 1st party site data. Audiences, I might add, that are going untargeted today due to the industry’s belief that things can’t be done any other way than with cookies.

If I could summarize this article in one statement it would be this; you need to be testing solutions now! You need to get comfortable with substitute alternatives for 3rd party cookies well before the end of this calendar year. Simply put, you cannot take for granted that there will be a like for like substitute for how you do things today so it’s time to accept and move forward.

AdTech should be making life as simple as possible for both advertisers and publishers to minimize the risk and maximize the opportunities associated with a cookieless future. I believe that, over time, there will be a usable share of traffic from unified identifiers yet at the same time, I also think that there will be a significant amount of audience volume derived from a publisher’s own 1st party site data. Audiences, I might add, that are going untargeted today due to the industry’s belief that things can’t be done any other way than with cookies.

0.name: Cookieless Is Not Near, It’s Here!

author.name: James Colborn
author.description:
I’m a qualified and experienced business leader with years of working in marketing, product sales strategy, selling and operations roles. I’ve been fortunate to experience working for amazing companies in both the United Kingdom and United States in an online advertising industry that has given me challenge and excitement. 

For the past 20+ years, I’ve led advertising and marketing practices for corporations like Microsoft, AOL and Verizon, around the globe. I’ve managed various disciplines during this time, from marketing, product marketing to sales strategy and operations. 

My skill is simplifying a decision, a course of action, a business model or an argument by using data, logic and clarity. My business is using these skills to connect advertisers and agencies with their desired audiences, with outcomes and with insight. 

I am a great communicator. I lead with vision and direction. I thrive in execution and I revel in the success of those I work for and those I work with. I have won accolades at every company I’ve worked for in management, leadership and teamwork. 

Outside of the corporate world, I relish in coaching race car drivers to find success in our collective passion for autosports. While the environment is totally different, the process is exactly the same. Finding simplicity in race car telemetry and communicating actionable decisions for racers to make.

Specialities: marketing, product marketing, online advertising, digital marketing, leadership, coaching, management, sales strategy, programmatic advertising, search engine marketing, data strategy, data management, data analysis, sales enablement.

In February of this year, an eMarketer report (US Programmatic Digital Display Ad Spending 2022) suggests that the majority of advertisers and publishers are first and foremost looking to test ‘authenticated and or email solutions’ (63%) and, most positively embrace contextual solutions (52%). This said, the minority will be testing ‘cohorts or probabilistic modeling’ (at 33% and 28% respectively) which may well be misaligned with the timeline of what’s going to be available and when especially when advertisers themselves have to determine their own value exchange for getting the necessary permissions to continue to reach their consumers.    Now at this point, this article might seem negative toward an addressable future so I’d like to stress that I firmly believe that any consumer involvement in a value exchange to create that addressable connection is of huge importance. Important because it spans so much more than audience targeting, from measurement to planning and important because the consumer’s involvement is exactly what privacy advocates and technology providers are looking for as these changes are rolled out. 4.headline: Cookieless Is Not Near, It’s Here!
4.description: While we are all getting ‘ready’ for a cookieless future, there are two major considerations that just aren’t being discussed enough.
4.articleBody:
Despite the fact it feels like we’ve all just started 2022, it’s only days until the end of Q1. That’s another quarter closer to a digital advertising ecosystem without 3rd party cookies. While conversations are all talking about preparation and getting ‘ready’ for a cookieless future, there are two major considerations that just aren’t being discussed enough; the industry is far from ready and immediate opportunities are constantly being ignored. Let me explain.
The missing 40%
I watched a fantastic TED Talk video the other day by the late (and quite simply wonderful) Sir Ken Robinson in which he commented “innovation is hard because it means doing something that isn’t very easy; it means challenging what we take for granted”. I’d argue this is the primary reason why we’re not talking enough about the fact that time is running out for implementing alternatives to the 3rd party cookie. Simply put, as long as campaigns can be delivered in full using Chrome, we’re still taking cookies for granted. In the Ted Video, Sir Ken further comments; “the great problem for transformation is the tyranny of common sense; thinking that things can’t be done any other way as that’s how it’s always been done”. 

What continues to surprise me, however, is the fact the industry dialogue is still talking about readiness and the ‘actions that are needed’ for a future without 3rd party cookies when we’re already waist deep in inventory pools that have been blocking 3rd party cookies for the past 4 years. That’s not a typo, the past 4 years! In some markets, the combined share of Safari and Firefox is greater than Chrome. On all of the impressions we’re able to monitor at Teads globally (and this is across the actions of 1.9BN people), the average missed opportunity is around 40% from Chrome and Firefox users, yet all eyes are still looking at Google because many can’t easily think of things being done any other way!
Not a question of when, but how
We move therefore need to question readiness. Are industry participants ready? In short, the answer is no. If we focus on publishers first, arguably the primary source of what’s available to advertisers to buy, a recent survey from Teads may help illustrate this point. Publishers believe - when asked to pick their primary initiatives for growth - that their focus for innovation and growth will come from contextual solutions (59%) and their own 1st party data (63%). Great if you are embracing contextual solutions and or predictive audiences built by machine learning and artificial intelligence. Adversely, the majority of publishers don’t have a strategy to get users to log-in (55%) for fear of disrupting the user experience and losing traffic and less than 20% have more than 2 out of 10 users logging-in today. Not so encouraging for those looking to adopt addressable identifier-based solutions.

Balance this supply conversation with areas of focus on demand. In February of this year, an eMarketer report (US Programmatic Digital Display Ad Spending 2022) suggests that the majority of advertisers and publishers are first and foremost looking to test ‘authenticated and or email solutions’ (63%) and, most positively embrace contextual solutions (52%). This said, the minority will be testing ‘cohorts or probabilistic modeling’ (at 33% and 28% respectively) which may well be misaligned with the timeline of what’s going to be available and when especially when advertisers themselves have to determine their own value exchange for getting the necessary permissions to continue to reach their consumers.

Now at this point, this article might seem negative toward an addressable future so I’d like to stress that I firmly believe that any consumer involvement in a value exchange to create that addressable connection is of huge importance. Important because it spans so much more than audience targeting, from measurement to planning and important because the consumer’s involvement is exactly what privacy advocates and technology providers are looking for as these changes are rolled out.
Update your digital priorities, today
What I’m really trying to convey is more of a reality check. A statement that says that while many solutions may have huge value, the question is one of timing, readiness and what can be achieved today, tomorrow and by the time the bell tolls on the demise of the 3rd party cookie.

AdTech should be making life as simple as possible for both advertisers and publishers to minimize the risk and maximize the opportunities associated with a cookieless future. I believe that, over time, there will be a usable share of traffic from unified identifiers yet at the same time, I also think that there will be a significant amount of audience volume derived from a publisher's own 1st party site data. Audiences, I might add, that are going untargeted today due to the industry's belief that things can’t be done any other way than with cookies.

If I could summarize this article in one statement it would be this; you need to be testing solutions now! You need to get comfortable with substitute alternatives for 3rd party cookies well before the end of this calendar year. Simply put, you cannot take for granted that there will be a like for like substitute for how you do things today so it’s time to accept and move forward.

AdTech should be making life as simple as possible for both advertisers and publishers to minimize the risk and maximize the opportunities associated with a cookieless future. I believe that, over time, there will be a usable share of traffic from unified identifiers yet at the same time, I also think that there will be a significant amount of audience volume derived from a publisher's own 1st party site data. Audiences, I might add, that are going untargeted today due to the industry's belief that things can’t be done any other way than with cookies.
